author: Matias Falcone
title: ALDEA Catalyst Spanish Support Site
description: There's a gap between Catalyst and a fast-growing Spanish Community, eager to participate and learn to do so in their native language.

assessments.note:
The problem and the solution are clear and reasonable. The proposal has scope within the challenge, as the translation of material could attract Spanish speakers, but the impact of the proposal is limited by some factors.

Voters will still have to deal with an English voting app.

Proposers can submit proposals in Spanish, but this can decrease their reach and

Community Advisors are currently unable to participate without understanding some English, as there are no mechanisms that allow assessments in other languages. At best they would have to use a text translator and in this case the purpose of this proposal is lost, because if we are counting on people to use text translators there is no sense that advisors need to read proposals translated manually.

Although these factors that I mentioned above are not decisive for voters and proposers, they reduce the impact of the proposal on value onboarding impact.
assessments.reply: The idea of ALDEA Catalyst is to help, support and encourage meaningful collaboration in Project Catalyst from the Latin American Community. We understand that voters will still have to deal with an English voting app and, while at the moment we can't do much about it, it doesn't mean ALDEA won't try to guide and help these voters so they can have a better understanding of the process. On the other hand, we never mentioned that Proposers will submit their proposals in Spanish: we talked about them receiving language support to submit their proposals in English, as the process right now is working that way. Finally, we believe that this assessment is unfair since it is attributing flaws of Project Catalyst to our Proposal, not only with the Voting App statement but also when it says: "Community Advisors are currently unable to participate without understanding some English, as there are no mechanisms that allow assessments in other languages. At best they would have to use a text translator and in this case the purpose of this proposal is lost, because if we are counting on people to use text translators there is no sense that advisors need to read proposals translated manually." This is exactly what we would like to address and fix with our Proposal, rather than something we are causing to be this way.

assessments.note: Translation of proposals and other documents into different languages, especially Spanish, is crucial for the future of Project Catalyst and therefore Cardano. If possible, wouldn't it be most effective it were complimentary to the Ideascale website and not an entirely new one? However, as one of the comments pointed out, there can be no system for choosing which proposal gets translated and which not.
assessments.reply: The idea of ALDEA Catalyst is not ONLY to translate Proposals: we are adding value and encouraging meaningful participation from the Latin American Community by providing the tools they need to better understand how Project Catalyst works and guide them on how they can find opportunities to develop valuable skills for the ecosystem.

assessments.note: Seems like a good area to fund. Catalyst community needs to be inclusive of non-English first language members and Spanish is a broadly spoken component.

The proposal is good and it addresses a real problem that is the participation of people that are not fluent in English in the Catalyst community. It seems reasonable to create such a platform today. In the future, I believe that a single platform with different languages interaction should be created and it would not be needed to have one platform for each language. But today it's necessary, and this proposal addresses it quite well.

This proposal doesn't require great technical complexity, only people with skills in web development and translators. From the development point of view there are indications that the team is able to execute the proposal. It is unclear who will perform the translation or the team's ability to translate. My point is:

Will this be a professional translation? I don't see the need for a professional translation, as the focus is on transmitting the content, but about 80% of the proposal's budget will be used for the translation of proposals, and it should be noted that, using an extension in the browser, a user can achieve practically the same quality of translation and will probably achieve the same understanding.

If we are thinking about translation quality it may be that an automatic translator is not perfect, but if the aim is a professional translation it would be important to describe the team's experience in translation.

Translation costs are inconclusive, as the definition of translation cost was established in cost per hour and not cost per word, without a definition of proposals to be translated or payment to be made per translated word, the auditability became hard to measure.

There is a justified concern with the translation of Catalyst material to expand the reach in communities that speak other languages ​​/ do not understand English, however it is necessary to reflect on the feasibility of translating proposals, as this would generate a great additional cost and would end up maintaining the community in silos, since for people who speak different languages ​​they need to interact at some point and this proposal doesn't solve this problem.

Some risks that I think are important to mention:

There is mention that only part of the proposals will be translated, I think it is important to define this more clearly, as this makes the translation process arbitrary, it can be any number. In addition, a conflict of interest may arise, as the translation and curation of these proposals would be limited to the intention of the ALDEA team.
assessments.reply: The review started with: "This proposal doesn't require great technical complexity, only people with skills in web development and translators. From the development point of view there are indications that the team is able to execute the proposal. It is unclear who will perform the translation or the team's ability to translate." Although we agree that we didn't provide enough information on who will perform the translations (we have many translators in ALDEA Community), this assessment only mentions that we are going to translate proposals and does not mention that we are also going to write a review about them so that people without technical knowledge about Cardano, Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies can also understand them. We think that is the most valuable part of the "translation side" of our Proposal.

assessments.note: The team has provided all the necessary information. They have an ample combined experience that does not cast any doubt on their implementation capabilities. Besides that, they have already started their discord server and the landing page for the website. They have a good plan that can easily be implemented.

Based on the team's experience and what they have already done, I believe it's very feasible to achieve the desired goals for Phase 1, which would be funded with this proposal. The only point that's a bit off is the cost for website development, which seems to be too small, and the Discord upgrades are not all listed as well so it's not possible to evaluate if that's feasible, but the remaining topics are achievable.

Translation costs are inconclusive, as the definition of translation cost was established in cost per hour and not cost per word, without a definition of proposals to be translated or payment to be made per translated word, the auditability became hard to measure.

The KPIs cited are not KPIs but metrics, but they are relevant metrics and good indicators of performance and success of the proposal, however the absence of KPIs makes auditing difficult in an objective way.

Although there are details about the qualifications of the team, there is no information about the need for a professional translator, if necessary it would be important to describe details about this person (the reason I am including this detail was mentioned during the assessment). There is a link to the Aldea DAO website, on the website there is information about the SPOs participating in the DAO, but there are no names and details about the members, which makes it difficult for the community to have more information.

All the information they have added is easily verifiable. They have split the project among several funding rounds, thus making it easier for the community to continue funding them, if the previous rounds prove to be valuable.

The proposers have listed a number of KPI's which is great. However without any targets on those, progress and success can not be measured. If the KPI's are important, they should have associated targets.

The success criteria is clear, and the suggested KPIs/metrics are also relevant to the problem. General milestones are good too. The budget breakdown shows that most of the money would go to translation, but Ii believe that it's a bit off since the Discord improvement and website development might cost more than what's stated there.

solution: ALDEA Catalyst is a site for people to find information in Spanish about Catalyst and develop hot valuable skills for the ecosystem.
experience: Falcon Cardano Stakepool & ALDEA Core Team. Senior IT Geeks, Entrepreneurs, WyoHackathon Winners & Long-Term Cardano Advocates.
